Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: I was reviewing a patient’s chart when my phone buzzed with a message from my younger brother: “Can you talk? It’s urgent.” He never used that word lightly. My mind raced with worry, but I had a patient waiting—a woman with a runny nose and a mild cough, likely just a cold, but I needed to be thorough. As a doctor, I owed her my full attention, to listen carefully, to not miss anything serious. But as a sister, I felt a pull so strong it almost hurt. My brother and I had always leaned on each other in tough times, and I knew he wouldn’t reach out unless he truly needed me. I could hear my patient’s voice in the next room, waiting for reassurance, while my brother’s message glowed on my screen, waiting for comfort. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the person who needed my care and the family who needed my support.
